titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Harriet Park Cramer photographic collection

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-11-03.

langusage.language: Finding aid is written in English.

profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid based on DACS (Describing Archives: A Content Standard), 2nd Edition.

physdesc.extent: 8 folders in shared box; 62 negatives in shared box

did.abstract: Photographic prints and nitrate negatives depicting Caroline Augusta Kamm, the Kamm children, and the Kamm house in Portland, Oregon; Elijah "Lige" Coalman; children and staff at the Fruit and Flower mission; and the grounds of the E. B. MacNaughton estate.

acqinfo.p: Gifts of Owen P. Cramer in March 1981 (Lib. Acc. 15461, Photo Acc. 981D044) and March 1988 (Lib. Acc. 18820, Photo Acc. 988D062).

bioghist.p: Jacob Kamm was born in 1823 in Switzerland. He came the United States as a small child with his parents. He was a pioneer steamboat engineer and transportation tycoon who made his fortune in Oregon. He became part-owner in the Jennie Clark, the first sternwheeler in the Pacific Northwest. He married Caroline Gray in 1859. He was one of the founders of the Oregon Steam Navigation Company with John C. Ainsworth. His company, the Oregon Steam Navigation Company, controlled boats on all the important western rivers. He died in Portland in 1912.

phystech.p: Negatives are not available for direct access due to fragility; contact library staff for assistance.

prefercite.p: Harriet Park Cramer photographic collection, Org. Lot 477, Oregon Historical Society Research Library.

scopecontent.p: Collection includes 83 black and white photographs, 1931, of Elijah "Lige" Coalman; Caroline Augusta Kamm at the Kamm home; the Kamm children, including Carolyn and Katherine; the interior, exterior, grounds, and gardens of the Kamm house; children and staff at the Fruit and Flower mission; and the grounds of the E. B. MacNaughton estate. The collection also includes 62 nitrate negatives.

userestrict.p: The Oregon Historical Society owns the materials in the Research Library and makes available reproductions for research, publication, and other uses. The Society does not necessarily hold copyright to all materials in the collections. In some cases, permission for use may require seeking additional authorization from copyright owners.
